title-group.article-title: Effects of Therapeutic Touch on Anxiety, Vital Signs, and Cardiac Dysrhythmia in a Sample of Iranian Women Undergoing Cardiac Catheterization
title-group.subtitle: A Quasi-Experimental Study

contrib.aff: Nursing & Midwifery Care Research Center, Tehran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran
Research Center for Modeling in Health, Kerman University of Medical Sciences, Kerman, Iran
Fatemeh (P.B.U.H) School of Nursing & Midwifery, Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Shiraz, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mitra Zolfaghari, Nursing & Midwifery Care Research Center, Tehran University of Medical Science, Tohid Square East Nosrat Street, Tehran 1419733171, Iran; e-mail: zolfaghm@tums.ac.ir.

abstract.p: Purpose of the study: To investigate the effects of Therapeutic Touch (TT) on anxiety, vital signs, and cardiac dysrhythmia in women undergoing cardiac catheterization. Design: It was a quasi-experimental study. The participants had no history of hallucination, anxiety, or other psychological problems. Participants had to be conscious and have attained at least sixth-grade literacy level. Participants were randomly assigned into an intervention group (n = 23; received 10-15 minutes TT), a placebo group (n = 23; received 10-15 minutes simulated touch), and a control group (n = 23; did not receive any therapy). Data were collected using Spielberger’s anxiety test, cardiac dysrhythmia checklist, and vital signs recording sheet. Statistical analyses were considered to be significant at α = .05 levels. Findings: Sixty-nine women ranging in age from 35 to 65 years participated. TT significantly decreased state anxiety p < 0.0001 but not trait anxiety (p = .88), decreased the incidence of all cardiac dysrhythmias p < 0.0001 except premature ventricular contraction (p = .01), and regulated vital signs p < 0.0001 in the intervention group versus placebo and control group. Conclusions: TT is an effective approach for managing state anxiety, regulating vital signs, and decreasing the incidence of cardiac dysrhythmia during stressful situations, such as cardiac catheterization, in Iranian cardiac patients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The effects of psychological distress, such as anxiety, are becoming an increasing concern among patients suffering from cardiac dysfunction. Anxiety increases the likelihood of dysrhythmia, high blood pressure, acceleration of pulse rate, and even sudden cardiac death (Plach, 2006).

The negative effects of anxiety may be intensified when a patient is undergoing a stressful procedure such as cardiac catheterization (Taylor-Piliaea & Chairb, 2002). Unmanaged stress and anxiety of patients who are undergoing cardiac catheterization may lead to considerable side effects, such as cardiac dysrhythmia, vessel spasm, and vessel laceration (Okvat, Oz, Ting, & Namerow, 2002). McNamara, Burnham, Smith, and Carroll (2003) also stated that cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure that can be perceived as a threat to the state of health and consequently lead to a negative reaction of the autonomic nervous system, in particular the sympathetic response. To prevent or reduce cardiac catheterization complications, it is necessary to assess the level of anxiety and the patient’s ability to cope with stress before catheterization and then plan appropriate interventions to help manage the stressful situation (McCaffrey & Taylor, 2005). Therefore, exploring effective ways to minimize patients’ anxiety before and during cardiac catheterization is essential. One effective strategy in managing stress and anxiety is Therapeutic Touch (TT; Robinson, Biley, & Dolk, 2007).

TT was originally developed by Dora Kunz and Dolores Krieger in the 1970s (Robinson et al., 2007) on the assumption that the human being is an energy field. Theoretically, TT was originally developed from Rogers’s theory, “The Science of Unitary Human Being,” which considers the human being as an energy field (D. W. Smith & Broida, 2007). TT is a process of energy exchange, in which the practitioner directs the hands on the patient’s body, focusing on healing. According to Krieger, imbalance in the patterns of energy around the body may appear as illness and can be assessed and repatterned by the provider of TT (Coppa, 2008). In recent decades, TT has been extensively applied in the health care arena, because it is inexpensive and applicable in most settings; the hands of the touch therapist are the only tools required for TT (Moeini, Zare, Hazrati, & Saghaei, 2008).

Several studies have investigated the effect of TT on health-related outcomes (Table 1). Despite the wide usage of alternative techniques such as TT in health care settings, evidence to support their effectiveness is scarce (Blankfield, Sulzmann, Fradley, Tapolyai, & Zyzanski, 2001). Moreover, many studies have been conducted to examine TT’s effect on different variables, but most have been criticized for their methodological defects, such as vague descriptions of the TT process (Peters, 1999), failure to use a placebo group, use of inappropriate assessment tools, and methodological flaws (Robinson et al., 2007). In addition, there are some disagreements with regard to the effectiveness of TT, and several authors do not consider TT as an effective approach for improving patient’s health (Olson & Sneed, 1995; Rosa, Rosa, Sarner, & Barrett, 1998). In a systematic review, Robinson et al. (2007) concluded that there have been only a few rigorous randomized or quasi- experimental studies examining the effects of TT on state anxiety and a limited number of studies conducted on trait anxiety. Moreover, even less is known about the effects of TT on cardiac dysrhythmia and vital signs in high-risk situations such as cardiac catheterization. Our aim, therefore, was to investigate the effects of TT on state and trait anxiety, vital signs, and cardiac dysrhythmia in women undergoing cardiac catheterization.

caption.p: Studies of the Effect of Therapeutic Touch on Health-Related Outcomes

tr.td: Pain and fatigue in cancer patients
Anxiety before coronary artery bypass graft surgery
Anxiety and pain during breast biopsy

Agitation behavior of patients with dementia

fn.label: b.
fn.p: Integrating Therapeutic Touch into cognitive behavioral therapy.

sec.title: Study Design and Participants
sec.p: A quasi-experimental design was implemented to conduct the study. A convenience sample of 69 women was selected. Participants were be included if they were electively admitted to Jamaran hospital with a diagnosis of coronary artery disease, were undergoing nonemergent diagnostic cardiac catheterization for the first time, had no history of hospitalization for cardiac problems (e.g., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmia, heart surgery, etc.) or diagnosed psychological problems (e.g., hallucinations or anxiety disorders), and were conscious and able to read and write independently. The consumption of antianxiety or opioid drugs 24 hours before or after catheterization was considered as an exclusion criterion for the study; however, no one met this criterion.

G-Power program was used to calculate the initial sample size for comparing the mean in two groups. Using an effect size of 0.54, an error chance of 0.05, and a power of 0.8, 16 samples were obtained for each group. We had three comparison groups (I, Intervention group, who received 10-15 minutes of TT an hour before cardiac catheterization; II, Placebo group, who received 10-15 minutes of simulated touch; and III, Control group, who did not receive any therapy); therefore, we made a correction for the sample size using the corresponding formula and obtained a final sample of 23 for each study group (total sample size was 69).

We used block randomization method to ensure the balance of the subject numbers in the study groups. Block randomization was executed by a nurse, blind to the study, using a random number table and a block size of three. Overall, six blocks were generated; numbers 1 to 6 were allocated to the blocks; if the nurse encountered numbers 0, 7, 8, or 9, she skipped that number until she arrived at one of the permitted numbers. Finally 69 participants were randomly assigned to three groups.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics
sec.p: These were assessed with respect to seven items, including age, educational level, marital status, number of children if applicable, employment, history of hospitalization, and duration of cardiovascular complication such as fatigue, chest pain, and so on (prior to admission).

sec.title: Anxiety
sec.p: Participants’ state and trait anxiety was measured an hour before (pretest) and immediately before (posttest) catheterization, using the Spielberger Anxiety Inventory (see Figure 1). The questionnaire consists of two parts that measure state (20 items) and trait anxiety (20 items) and was completed by participants.

caption.p: Intervention and Measurement Details in Therapeutic Touch, Placebo, and Control Groups

Note: † Including demographic and health-related variables; § including respiration rate, pulse rate, and blood pressure; ¤ state and trait anxiety measured by the Spielberger Anxiety Inventory; ¤¤ cardiac dysrhythmia; * cardiac catheterization; ** control group did not receive real or simulated TT; ° Therapeutic Touch, placebo, and control groups.

sec.title: Vital signs
sec.p: Patients’ vital signs including systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and respiration rate were recorded an hour before (pretest) and during the catheterization (posttest) using a vital sign record sheet (see Figure 1).

sec.title: Cardiac dysrhythmia
sec.p: Cardiac dysrhythmia was assessed during cardiac catheterization using a checklist consisting of seven common dysrhythmia, including premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), premature atrial contractions, ventricular tachycardia, sinus tachycardia, sinus bradycardia, premature nodal contraction, and sudden cardiac death. A strip was recorded if a dysrhythmia occurred.

sec.title: Validity
sec.p: Those baseline characteristics with an impact on the study’s outcomes were derived from the literature (Aghabati, Mohammadi, & PourEsmaiel, 2010; McNamara et al., 2003). Based on the literature and expert opinion, we developed a checklist of the most common dysrhythmias in cardiac catheterization (seven dysrhythmias). Then, the content and face validity of the baseline characteristics questionnaire and dysrhythmia checklist were examined by attaining the opinion of 10 experts in the field of nursing and cardiology and minor revisions were made.

The Spielberger Anxiety Inventory is a widely used valid tool developed by Spielberger, Gorsuch, and Lushene (1970) with a reliability of α = .54 for state anxiety and α = .86 for trait anxiety. It has also been translated into the Persian language, standardized, and approved for validity and reliability by Panahi (1994). Cronbach’s alpha of the translated version was α = .55 for state anxiety and α = .84 for trait anxiety. Permission to use the tool was obtained from the translator. This instrument is applicable for those with a minimum of sixth-grade literacy.

sec.title: Reliability
sec.p: Two nurses, blinded to the study, measured vital signs in both pretest and posttest points, using a single calibrated device for each part (one for the ward and one for the catheterization room). The nurses also matched both pieces of equipment with each other, to ensure that higher reliability was obtained. To examine the reliability of measuring cardiac dysrhythmia, the cardiologist and the researcher simultaneously assessed and concurred on the occurrence of dysrhythmia during catheterization (see Figure 1).

sec.title: Intervention
sec.p: Since the introduction of TT by Kunz and Krieger in the 1970s (Robinson et al., 2007), Nurse Healers–Professional Associates International (NH-PAI) has become the certified organization for TT. Each participant in the intervention group received TT, using the process described by Nurse Healers–Professional Associates International (2008). The process consists of the following: (a) explain the procedure to the patient; (b) concentrate on the patient; (c) decide to assist with the patient’s therapy; (d) assess the patient’s energy field by moving the palms of the hands from the patient’s head to his or her toes, with the hands approximately 2 to 4 inches away from the his or her body; (e) move the hands in a gentle and rhythmic manner to repattern the imbalances in the energy field, continuing until the energy field is completely balanced; (f) reevaluate the energy field, give a break to the patient, and appraise his or her response.

In the placebo group, who received simulated touch, the researcher imitated the process of real touch. The real touch was simulated as follows: (a) explain the procedure to the patient, but the patient is not to be notified about the possibility of simulated touch; (b) do not concentrate; (c) do not decide to help; (d) do not assess the patient’s energy field, and move the hands 7 to 8 inches away from the body; (e) objectively imitate the process of moving the hands; (f) give a break to the patient and appraise the patient’s response.

TT and simulated touch were carried out in the intervention group by a researcher who was skilled and qualified in TT, had undertaken a specific 6- month TT course, and had 2 years of experience in this area. Both the therapeutic and simulated touch took between 10 to 15 minutes. The control group did not receive any touch. All groups (TT, placebo, and control) received the same standard medical care, including intravenous diazepam (2 mg).

sec.title: Ethical Considerations
sec.p: Approval was obtained from the ethics committee of Tehran University of Medical Sciences (TUMS). The purpose of the study and its confidentiality were clearly explained to the participants. Written informed consent was obtained from the participants.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Data were analyzed using SPSS software (Version 11.5). Descriptive statistics were employed to describe baseline characteristics. To compare the homogeneity of the three groups with regard to all baseline data (except age) and cardiac dysrhythmia, chi-square tests were applied. To evaluate the difference in participants mean age, vital signs, and anxiety between the three groups, analysis of variance was used. To determine the group, which had a different mean to the other groups, post hoc test (with least significant difference method) was used. Paired t tests were used to compare differences between patients’ anxiety, cardiac dysrhythmia, and vital signs, before and after intervention, in each group.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Sixty-nine women participated in the current study. Their age ranged from 35 to 65 years (mean = 51.05 years, SD = 7.27). Most of the participants were married (n = 66, 95.6%) and homemakers (n = 56, 81.2%). The majority had no history of hospitalization for noncardiovascular complaints, either medical or surgical (n = 52, 73.4%). A high proportion of the participants had sixth-grade literacy level (n = 31, 44.9%; Table 2).

caption.p: Comparison Between Three Groups With Regard to Participants’ Baseline Characteristics

fn.p: Note: TT = Therapeutic Touch; df = degrees of freedom.

sec.p: At pretest, there was no significant difference between the three groups with regard to baseline data (Table 2), trait and state anxiety, and vital signs (Table 3). However, at posttest, there was significant difference between the three groups in patients’ vital signs and state anxiety but not in trait anxiety (between-group degrees of freedom = 2, within-group degrees of freedom = 66, F = 3.03, p = .88). With respect to the least significant difference post hoc test results, there was a significant difference in patients’ state anxiety between the TT group and the placebo and control groups (p < .0001). The mean score of patients’ vital signs was also lower in the TT group when compared with the placebo and control group at this time (Table 3).

caption.p: Comparison of Anxiety and Vital signs in the TT, Placebo, and Control Groups, Before and During Catheterization

fn.p: Note: TT = Therapeutic Touch; ANOVA = analysis of variance; df = degrees of freedom. *t test; **ANOVA.

fn.label: a.
fn.p: TT versus placebo and control groups.

sec.p: Paired t test results showed that in the TT group, the mean of anxiety and vital signs decreased posttest; the reduction in mean score of anxiety (state, p < .0001; trait, p = .027) and respiration rate (p < .0001) was statistically significant. In placebo and control groups, paired t test results showed an increase in patients’ mean of anxiety and vital signs at posttest. The increase was statistically significant for vital signs (in both placebo and control groups; p < .0001), state anxiety (in control group; p < .0001), and trait anxiety (in placebo group; p < .047; Table 3).
Incidence of all cardiac dysrhythmias (except PVC) in the TT group was significantly lower than the control and placebo groups (p < .05; Table 4).

caption.p: Comparison of Cardiac Dysrhythmia During Catheterization Between Intervention, Placebo, and Control Groups

fn.p: Note: ST = sinus tachycardia; VT = ventricular tachycardia; PAC = premature atrial contraction; PAT = premature atrial tachycardia; PVC = premature ventricular contraction.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Complementary and alternative therapies (e.g., energy therapies, mind–body medicine, biologically based practices, etc.) are widely used in health care; however, little objective evidence is available for determining their effectiveness. Our results indicate that TT can significantly decrease state anxiety before catheterization, regulate vital signs, and decrease the incidence of cardiac dysrhythmia during catheterization in Iranian women.

Six investigations reported significant effects of TT in reducing state anxiety: one study with elderly population (Lin & Taylor, 1998), four studies with hospitalized patients (Click, 1996; Cox & Hayes, 1999; Gagne & Toye, 1994; Munro, Creamer, Haggerty, & Cooper, 1988), and one study with nurses (McElligott et al., 2003). Bowers (1992) applied TT on preoperative patients and assessed its effect on state anxiety but failed to find any significant effects. This may have been because of the small sample size (20 subjects: 12 experimental and 8 controls) or the time the intervention was applied (1 hour after hospital admission). Kelly, Sullivan, Fawcett, and Samarel (2004) evaluated the effect of TT and nurse dialogue on cancer patients’ mood, anxiety, and postoperative pain. They failed to find any significant effects of TT on anxiety. This may also have been because of the small sample size (n = 18); moreover, patients’ anxiety, mood, and pain were assessed subjectively using a qualitative approach.

Short duration of TT in this study (10-15 minutes in a single session, 1 hour before catheterization) could not significantly affect participants’ trait anxiety (Larden, Palmer, & Janssen, 2004). Although some level of sedation was gained after one session of therapy in TT group, delayed effects on trait anxiety can be addressed only after further sessions, depending on patient need. Larden et al. evaluated the effect of TT on withdrawal symptoms of chemically dependent inpatient pregnant women. The results showed that TT significantly decreased patients’ anxiety in Days 1 to 3 but showed no effect after 7 days or more; in other words, they found an instant, but not a delayed, effect of TT on anxiety, which is relatively congruent with our results.

TT also significantly decreased PR during catheterization in TT group, which is congruent with other studies (Click, 1996; Heidt, 1981; Randolph, 1984). Moreover, patients’ RR and BP decreased significantly in TT group. Regulation of patients’ vital signs may be associated with nervous system regulation (Randolph, 1984) or sedation and comfort gained by TT (Click, 1996; Cox & Hayes, 1999; Newshan & Schuller-Civitella, 2003; D. W. Smith & Broida, 2007; M. C. Smith, Reeder, Daniel, Baramee, & Hagman, 2003). Randolph (1984) noted that TT probably regulates autonomic nervous system function and consequently normalizes the vital signs of the patient. Although vital sign regulation has been reported to be associated with sedation and comfort in TT receivers, its causal pathway is not clear. Further investigations are needed to explore the mechanism of vital sign regulation during the implementation of TT.

Incidence of all cardiac dysrhythmias (except PVC) in the TT group was significantly lower than in the control and placebo groups. We could find no investigation that had taken this matter into account; therefore, we were unable to make a comparison. It would seem that the sedation and comfort obtained after TT are responsible for such results. For PVC (which did not show a significant decrease in TT group), we believe that the contact of the catheter with the ventricle during the catheterization procedure and catheterization-induced ventricular ischemia could provoke PVC even if the state of a patient’s anxiety has been controlled by TT (Opie & Clusin, 1990).

The use of different equipment to assess patients’ vital signs in pretest and posttest points and a single calibrated device (one for the ward and one for catheterization room) in pretest and posttest points enabled the researcher to control the lack of reliability. Matching both pieces of equipment also enabled the researcher to confirm the reliability of the data.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Several limitations of the study need to be acknowledged. Taking 2 mg intravenous diazepam as a routine sedative drug before cardiac catheterization may affect vital signs and can be considered as a limitation. However, all participants in TT, placebo, and control group were homogenous in receiving this standard therapy.

It is possible that the therapist could switch to real TT while trying to “simulate” the TT in the placebo group. To minimize this limitation, the therapist held the palms of their hands about 7 to 8 inches away from the patients’ body (in TT procedure the accurately defined distance is 2-3 inches).

Because the study was conducted in women aged 35 to 65 years, the possible effect of menopausal status on TT outcomes is not clear and should be considered in future investigations. The small sample size is also another limitation for generalizability of the results.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: TT in patients undergoing cardiac catheterization can be considered as an effective strategy to decrease state anxiety and potential cardiac dysrhythmia during catheterization and to regulate vital signs in Iranian women. However, further investigations with a larger sample, various age-groups, and both genders are suggested. Nurse practitioners can use TT to improve outcomes in patients undergoing cardiac catheterization or in similar stressful situations in Iran.

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: This article has resulted from a research study approved by Tehran University of Medical Sciences’ (TUMS) Research Deputy. We hereby acknowledge the Research Deputy of the TUMS for providing the facilities required. We also thank the respected colleagues in the hospital and catheterization ward and kind patients who collaborated with us in this project.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Mitra Zolfaghari was born in Shiraz (Iran) in 1970, educated in Shiraz University of Medical Science (SUMS) for bachelors and master of Nursing and in Piam Nour University for PhD level studies. She is a member of Nursing & Midwifery Care Research Center at Tehran University of Medical Sciences (TUMS), Iran.

Sana Eybpoosh was born in Urmia (Iran) in 1984, educated in TUMS for bachelors and master of nursing and continues her PhD level studies in the field of epidemiology at Kerman University of Medical Sciences, Iran.

Maryam Hazrati was born in Shiraz (Iran) in 1957, educated in SUMS for bachelors and master of Nursing and continued her PhD level studies in the field Giantrology at Malaysia University. She is a faculty member of Nursing & Midwifery School at SUMS, Iran.
